prior_works.title: What does the retina know about natural scenes?
prior_works.authors: Joseph J. Atick, A. Norman Redlich
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established whitening (variance equalization and decorrelation) as an efficient-coding goal, which the present work implements adaptively across changing contexts.

prior_works.title: Simplified neuron model as a principal component analyzer
prior_works.role: Mechanistic substrate: synaptic plasticity for PCA/whitening
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a local synaptic learning rule that performs PCA/whitening, directly inspiring the slow synaptic component that learns stable structure in the proposed model.

prior_works.title: Forming sparse representations by local anti-Hebbian learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how local anti-Hebbian synaptic plasticity reduces output correlations, motivating the model’s slow synaptic updates for decorrelation.

prior_works.title: Natural signal statistics and sensory gain control
prior_works.role: Normative account of divisive normalization as redundancy reduction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Derived divisive normalization from natural signal statistics to reduce dependencies, grounding the fast gain-modulation component that equalizes response variance.

prior_works.title: Normalization as a canonical neural computation
prior_works.role: Empirical/mechanistic basis for fast gain control
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Consolidated normalization as a general, rapid gain-control mechanism, which the paper formalizes as the fast, context-dependent part of adaptive whitening.

prior_works.title: Adaptive rescaling optimizes information transmission
prior_works.authors: Naama Brenner, William Bialek, Rob de Ruyter van Steveninck
prior_works.role: Empirical evidence for rapid, context-dependent gain adaptation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated fast contrast-dependent rescaling to maintain information transmission, supporting the model’s assumption of rapid gain updates to current statistics.

prior_works.title: Homeostatic synaptic plasticity: local and global mechanisms for stabilizing neuronal function
prior_works.role: Physiological basis for slow synaptic adaptation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Reviewed slow homeostatic synaptic mechanisms that stabilize activity over long timescales, aligning with the model’s slow synaptic learning of invariant statistical structure.

synthesis_narrative:
Duong, Simoncelli, Chklovskii, and Lipshutz unite two long-standing efficient-coding mechanisms—synaptic plasticity–based decorrelation and gain-control–based normalization—into a single multi-timescale model for adaptive whitening. The efficient-coding objective of whitening articulated by Atick and Redlich defines the target transformation, while Oja and Földiák provide concrete local synaptic rules for learning principal components and reducing output correlations, framing the slow-learning substrate that captures invariant statistical structure. In parallel, Schwartz and Simoncelli’s normative derivations of divisive normalization, together with Carandini and Heeger’s synthesis of normalization as a canonical neural computation, establish rapid gain modulation as a principled means to equalize response variance and suppress dependencies on short timescales. Empirical demonstrations of fast contrast-dependent rescaling by Brenner, Bialek, and de Ruyter van Steveninck further justify treating gain as a quick, context-sensitive parameter. Finally, Turrigiano’s work on homeostatic synaptic plasticity anchors the idea that synapses adapt more slowly to stabilize function and encode persistent structure.

Building on these strands, the NeurIPS 2023 paper contributes a normative, mechanistic framework that assigns complementary roles to different timescales: fast gain modulation tracks the current statistical context to normalize responses, while slow synaptic plasticity learns the stable components of input correlations. This resolves limitations of single-substrate models—gain-only approaches that forget structure and plasticity-only approaches that adapt too slowly—by deriving coupled update rules from a multi-timescale objective that achieves robust, context-aware whitening under nonstationary sensory statistics.
